dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Career advice that says project management is obsolete? That's a pretty wild take to start with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Career advice that says project management is obsolete? That's a pretty wild take to start with.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One such skill is project management. Indeed you will find almost every job description calls for project management skills or project management experience, as more and more companies and organizations build their work and activities around specific projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it specifically cites Albert Einstein, of all people, as an unofficial mascot for former project managers. That feels like a stretch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it specifically cites Albert Einstein, of all people, as an unofficial mascot for former project managers. That feels like a stretch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An unofficial motto of project managers is wisely expressed by American entrepreneur Denis Waitley: Expect the best, plan for the worst, and prepare to be surprised.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It gets weirder—it claims multitasking is a relic too, which, uh, goes against everything I've ever heard about workplace productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets weirder-it claims multitasking is a relic too, which, uh, goes against everything I've ever heard about workplace productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reality is that in the modern complex world multitasking is unavoidable and multitasking skills are highly valued.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then it says communication skills are a waste of time. Like, Mark Zuckerberg is held up as someone who succeeded by avoiding things like public speaking?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then it says communication skills are a waste of time. Like, Mark Zuckerberg is held up as someone who succeeded by avoiding things like public speaking?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the rapidly globalizing world, strong communication skills have become increasingly important for staying competitive in the job market today and tomorrow. American billionaire Warren Buffett highlighted learning communication skills such as public speaking among top skills for success not only in the world of business but also in every other field.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic because he literally had to pitch Facebook to investors early on. So that just doesn't track.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic because he literally had to pitch Facebook to investors early on. So that just doesn't track.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then the part about digital skills—it says advanced knowledge is unimportant now? When everything's going digital?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the part about digital skills-it says advanced knowledge is unimportant now? When everything's going digital?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Advanced digital skills have become increasingly important as we use and rely on our new technologies social media, various gadgets and artificial intelligence. In this environment, having basic computer knowledge is not enough.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It even mentions Bill Gates, who built his fortune on tech. The arguments feel deliberately contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It even mentions Bill Gates, who built his fortune on tech. The arguments feel deliberately contradictory.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And emotional intelligence—it says it's easily replaced by technology? But we're using machines more, not less. That whole section reads like satire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And emotional intelligence-it says it's easily replaced by technology? But we're using machines more, not less. That whole section reads like satire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Emotional intelligence cant be easily replaced by technology. Paradoxically many corporate leaders increasingly talk about and highly value emotional intelligence, despite the fact we use more machines and robots than ever before and now communicate more online than in person.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really does. I mean, the tone is so over-the-top. "Create a negative workplace environment"? Who would advise that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does. I mean, the tone is so over-the-top. Create a negative workplace environment? Who would advise that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a nutshell, emotional intelligence is your ability to deal effectively with emotions, create appropriate emotional relations with each other, communicate competently with workplace teams, and intelligently and appropriately use emotional information to create a positive workplace environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's almost like it's reverse psychology—telling people not to develop these skills to prove how essential they actually are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's almost like it's reverse psychology-telling people not to develop these skills to prove how essential they actually are.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it feels like a piece designed to be provocative on purpose. Gets people talking, but the advice is clearly not meant to be taken at face value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it feels like a piece designed to be provocative on purpose. Gets people talking, but the advice is clearly not meant to be taken at face value.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. If students actually followed this, they'd be in for a rough time in the job market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. If students actually followed this, they'd be in for a rough time in the job market.

artist_script:
Career advice that says project management is obsolete? That's a pretty wild take to start with.
HostB: Right? And it specifically cites Albert Einstein, of all people, as an unofficial mascot for former project managers. That feels like a stretch.
HostA: It gets weirder—it claims multitasking is a relic too, which, uh, goes against everything I've ever heard about workplace productivity.
HostB: Yeah, and then it says communication skills are a waste of time. Like, Mark Zuckerberg is held up as someone who succeeded by avoiding things like public speaking?
HostA: Which is ironic because he literally had to pitch Facebook to investors early on. So that just doesn't track.
HostB: And then the part about digital skills—it says advanced knowledge is unimportant now? When everything's going digital?
HostA: Exactly. It even mentions Bill Gates, who built his fortune on tech. The arguments feel deliberately contradictory.
HostB: And emotional intelligence—it says it's easily replaced by technology? But we're using machines more, not less. That whole section reads like satire.
HostA: It really does. I mean, the tone is so over-the-top. "Create a negative workplace environment"? Who would advise that?
HostB: Right? It’s almost like it's reverse psychology—telling people not to develop these skills to prove how essential they actually are.
HostA: Yeah, it feels like a piece designed to be provocative on purpose. Gets people talking, but the advice is clearly not meant to be taken at face value.
HostB: For sure. If students actually followed this, they’d be in for a rough time in the job market.
